title: VC Daily: Telehealth Providers Set to Face Pressure to Bulk Up in 2021
text:
"Once people try it and realize the convenience, it's hard to turn back," said Stephanie Davis, an analyst with investment banking firm SVB Leerink .

Now that the industry has grown more established, companies are racing to build comprehensive, one-stop shops enabling employers, health systems and others to gain access to a variety of telehealth services.

In October virtual-care provider Teladoc Health Inc . paid $18.5 billion to acquire a company with complementary offerings, Livongo Health Inc . Livongo specializes in helping patients manage chronic illnesses such as diabetes.

Teladoc's purchase puts pressure on competitors to also bulk up through acquisitions, a trend that will benefit telehealth startups in 2021.

And now on to the news...

Top News

Stimulus payments. The new federal stimulus is giving digital bank startups a chance to demonstrate their consumer-friendly chops, WSJ Pro's Yuliya Chernova reports.

* Banking startups Current and Chime said they began making stimulus payments available to customers on Tuesday, as soon as the government began sending payments to banks and earlier than some other banking institutions.

* "I'm sure people are happy to get their stimulus payment a day earlier, but it's not a reason to pick a bank," said Lauren Saunders , associate director of National Consumer Law Center , a nonprofit that advocates on behalf of low-income people.

$700 Million

The amount of federal stimulus payments that banking app Chime credited to customer accounts in the first couple of days after the government began disbursing funds to banks.

SoftBank to Get Majority Stake in Katerra With $200 Million Bailout

SoftBank Group Corp . has agreed to invest $200 million more to bail out Katerra, a construction startup that ran into financial problems as it tried to shake up the building industry, WSJ's Konrad Putzier reports.

Cyber Startups Face Broader Funding Challenge in 2021

Disruption caused by the coronavirus pandemic forced startups and their investors to rethink how they did business in 2020. This year, venture-capital firms say, companies that want to attract funding will have to move beyond established niches, while competing with global rivals and enduring greater scrutiny than in the past, James Rundle writes for WSJ Pro Cybersecurity.

Covid-19 Economy Boosts ‘Buy Now, Pay Later' Installment Services

Millions of U.S. consumers, looking to stretch their dollars and avoid taking on new credit-card debt during the coronavirus pandemic, flocked in recent months to "buy now, pay later" offers from financial-technology companies including Affirm Holdings Inc ., Afterpay Ltd . and Klarna Bank AB , WSJ reports.

Japan Plays Catch-Up in Venture Capital as Rivals Boom

As the world's two biggest economies, the U.S. and China send scores of startups to the public markets—some at jaw-dropping valuations—yet Japan, at No. 3, has been lagging far behind. The Japanese government wants to kick its startup scene into higher gear, but it won't be easy, WSJ reports.

Chernova's Take: Filecoin Faces Common Blockchain Challenge of Whether People Will Pay to Use It

By Yuliya Chernova

Filecoin, a file-storage network based on blockchain technology, originally backed in 2017 with more than $200 million, still has a lot to prove. The project, developed by startup Protocol Labs Inc., launched in October after more than three years in development. It now needs to get more people to use its file storage network so as to preserve its value and reach its goal of competing with the likes of Amazon Web Services . That can be tricky for a decentralized software network that doesn't control key aspects users care about such as pricing.

Read the full article.

Industry News

Funds

Seattle-based Madrona Venture Group closed $500 million across two new funds. Madrona Venture Fund VIII LP raised $345 million, or $45 million more than Fund VII in 2018. Madrona Acceleration Fund II secured $160 million in commitments, or $60 million above its preceding fund in 2019. Fund VIII will continue to invest mostly in seed and Series A rounds, with the new Acceleration fund focusing on Series B and Series C investments.

China and U.S. growth equity investor Oceanpine Capital closed its second fund with $400 million, the same amount the Beijing-based firm raised for its inaugural fund back in 2016. About half of the new fund has been deployed across ten deals, including funding rounds for AI computing company Enflame Technology, drug developer Apexigen and enterprise software provider XforcePlus.

Exits

Bloomberg LP acquired consumer-spending data tracker Second Measure for an undisclosed amount. San Mateo, Calif.-based Second Measure was backed by investors including Bessemer Venture Partners , Goldman Sachs , Citi Ventures , Norwest Venture Partners , Shasta Ventures and Foundation Capital.

FedEx Corp . closed its acquisition of ecommerce network ShopRunner, which was backed by August Capital , for an undisclosed amount.

Olympus Corp . will expand its respiratory product portfolio with the purchase of Veran Medical Technologies Inc . Terms weren't disclosed. St. Louis-based Veran was listed in the portfolios of River Cities Capital, Versant Ventures and Revelation Partners.

New Money

Graphcore, a U.K.-based maker of chips designed for the needs of artificial intelligence, secured $222 million in Series E funding that values the company at $2.77 billion. Led by Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board , the round also included participation from funds managed by Fidelity International and Schroders, along with previous backers Baillie Gifford and Draper Esprit .

WeRide, a Chinese autonomous driving startup, landed a $200 million strategic investment from Yutong Group to complete the company's Series B1 round. Renault-Nissan -Mitsubishi's Alliance Ventures invested in WeRide in 2018.

Flexiv Ltd., a Chinese robotics startup, raised more than $100 million in Series B funding from investors including Meituan, Meta Capital, New Hope Group, Longwood, YF Capital, Gaorong Capital, GSR Ventures and Plug and Play.

23andMe Inc ., a Sunnyvale, Calif.-based genetic testing provider, added $82.5 million in Series F financing co-led by Sequoia Capital and NewView Capital.

Echelon Fitness, a Chattanooga, Tenn.-based at-home fitness brand, closed a $65 million financing round. Goldman Sachs Growth led the investment, which included additional support from North Castle Partners .

Brightpearl Inc ., a U.K.- and Austin, Texas-based startup whose technology automates back office tasks for retailers and wholesalers, raised a £25 million ($33 million) Series C round. Sage led the investment, which included contributions from Cipio Partners , Notion Capital and Verdane.

CommonGround, a Los Altos, Calif.-. and Tel Aviv-based developer of technology to improve virtual meetings, picked up a $19 million investment. Matrix Partners led the round, which included participation from Grove Ventures and StageOne Ventures.

Crave Hospitality Group, a food-delivery platform, was seeded with a $7.3 million investment led by StageDotO.

Biteable, a video template platform, fetched a $7 million investment led by Cloud Apps Capital Partners.

Dongnae, a Seoul-based residential real-estate startup, nabbed $4.1 million in seed funding. Flybridge and MetaProp led the round, and were joined by Goodwater Capital, Maple VC and others.

Ondato, a London-based authentication software developer, secured more than $2 million in seed financing from OTB Ventures and Startup Wise Guys.

Tech News

* Amazon agrees to buy podcast startup Wondery

* Record IPO surge set to roll on in 2021

* ‘Startup City': accelerated growth strains Austin

* Cisco Systems pulls back from smart city push

* Instacart looked like a savior. Now stores aren't so sure.

* These tech companies are paying workers the same rates across U.S.

* Uber, gig companies seek labor deals to avoid workers becoming employees

Around the Web

* How Silicon Valley turned a doomsday scenario into the hottest year for deals (The Information)

* Apple removes 39,000 game apps from China store to meet deadline (Reuters)

* China online education startup draws Alibaba in $1.6 billion funding round (Bloomberg)

* Trade-in site Gazelle is ending trade-ins (The Verge)

Correction

The company Paystack Payments Ltd. was incorrectly called Paystack Payment in the introduction of the Dec. 23 newsletter.
